TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY AT A GLANCE 

 

  I. 

THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 

Justification 

 
A. 
 
The transaction technical assistance facility (TRTA facility) will provide environment and 
1. 
social risk management, capacity building, and support to future and ongoing projects within the 
South  Asia  region.  The TRTA  facility  will  build  on  and  expand  the  scope  of  TA  8569-REG,  an 
earlier technical assistance (TA) that enhanced safeguards policy application in selected South 
Asia  region  developing  member  countries  (DMC). 1 Notwithstanding  the  achievements  of  TA 
8569-REG, the expansion of Asian Development Bank (ADB) operations in the region indicates 
that it is  imperative to maintain TA support. This is particularly relevant for infrastructure projects 
that typically involve significant environment and social risks such as urban transport and services, 
and  renewable  energy.  This  proposed  TRTA  facility  will  strengthen  the  capacity  of  key 
government units, civil society, academe, consultants, and contractors to design, implement, and 
monitor robust measures that address project risks to people and the environment.  
 
Alignment  with  Strategy  2030. 2  To  operationalize  the  priority  of  Strategy  2030  on 
2. 
strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity,  the  TRTA  facility  will  uphold  environment 
and social standards through more effective safeguards implementation and management.  While 
the focus on ADB-supported operations, the intervention is relevant and applicable to all projects 
regardless of financing.  
 
3. 
The  policy  frameworks  that  govern  safeguards,  including  the  ADB  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (SPS),3 seek to avoid, minimize, or mitigate adverse environment and social impacts 
of  investment  projects.  In  particular,  the  safeguard  policies  of  DMCs  and  multilateral  finance 
institutions  promote  the  mitigation  of  vulnerability,  a  major  risk  to  social  and  environment 
sustainability of projects, as well as protecting the rights of persons likely to be affected by the 
projects. Implementation of safeguard measures has thus necessarily become embedded in the 
process of project preparation and implementation as it enhances project sustainability.  
 
4. 
The  TRTA  facility  seeks  to  maintain  ADB’s  role  as  a  trusted  development  partner, 
delivering  quality  operations  while  adding  practical  value  to  projects  that  fit  local  conditions, 
identifying  lessons  learned,  and  replicating  good  practices  in  environment  and  social  risk 
management.  It  will  support  environment  and  social  safeguards  due  diligence,  consultation, 
supervision,  monitoring,  and  grievance  redress  in  ADB-funded  projects  in  all  the  South  Asian 
countries and sectors within these countries. This will be essential for the smooth preparation and 
implementation of the ADB’s 2020-2022 programs in South Asia DMCs. The programs include 
some 140 proposed projects involving a total of $22 billion in ADB funding.4 Of these projects, 
about 24% may have significant adverse environment and/or involuntary resettlement impacts, 
around  66%  may  have  less  significant  adverse  impacts,  and  only  approximately  10%  are 
expected to have no impacts. Projects with significant adverse and less adverse impacts require

 Outputs and Activities 

Since the proposed TRTA facility will cover all the South Asian countries, and ultimately 
5. 
sectors within these countries, it will not be appropriate or suitable to incorporate the proposed 
TRTA facility into a single loan-financed operations. This TRTA facility is not listed in the current 
Country Operations Business Plans (COBPs) of South Asia DMCs but will support projects listed 
in the respective COBPs (Appendix 1).5 Further, it will complement other TA projects in supporting 
improved  project  implementation  and  will  not  duplicate  ongoing  assistance  which  addresses 
portfolio management in general. 
 
B. 
 
6. 
Output 1: Environment and social risk management capacity improved. The TRTA 
facility will support environment and social safeguards capacity building of government agencies 
in  the  region.  It  will  continue  to  improve  safeguard  results  by  providing  hands-on  support  to 
executing  and  implementing  agencies  (EAs/IAs)  upon  request  or  assessment  by  ADB  project 
teams.  This  will  include  providing  assistance  to  civil  society,  academe,  contractors,  and 
consultants on the timely submission and improved quality of impact assessments and mitigation 
plans.  The  support  would  cover  as  necessary  the  entire  project  cycle,  from  the  preparation  of 
detailed project reports, due diligence reports, impact assessment and mitigation plans, internal 
and external monitoring reports, and assessments of safeguard results at project completion. The 
TRTA  facility  will  support  workshops  and  related  training  programs  on  environment  and  social 
safeguards.6 The training programs would be identified based on the assessment of capacity of 
project implementation agencies. In addition, consultants will be engaged to review and provide 
analysis of issues and proposed measures for safeguards strengthening. 
 
At least ten training programs will be conducted for staff of EAs/IAs, civil society, academe, 
7. 
contractors, and consultants on environment and social impact assessment, management plan, 
and  monitoring  reports  in  line  with  national,  agency,  and  sectoral  policies  and  ADB  SPS. 7 
Individual consultants will be engaged to conduct at least four studies on international safeguard 
best practices and standards. Individual consultants will undertake activities in close interaction 
with EAs/IAs, ADB, and other stakeholders.  
 
8. 
Output  2:  Project  management  and  supervision  capacity  of  executing  agencies 
strengthened using advanced technology applications. Cost reduction is a measure for more 
effective and efficient safeguards implementation. One of the ways is using advanced technology 
to improve efficiency in data collection. Advanced technology includes remote sensing, satellite 
imaging,  use  of  drones,  global  positioning  and  other  hand-held  devices,  and  web-based 
applications.  The  TRTA  facility  will  maintain  and  enhance  South  Asia  Department’s  (SARD) 
environment  and  social  safeguard  tracking  systems  and  develop  new  platforms  for  impact 
assessment,  monitoring,  and  grievance  redress.  Based  on  consultations  between  ADB  and 
relevant agencies in each country, the TRTA facility will identify one or two projects in selected 
DMCs to be the focus of advanced technology application. Individual consultants on advanced 
technology will be engaged to assist in the use of new technology. The application of advanced

9. 
At  least  two  workshops  and  related  training  programs  will  identify  and  focus  on  critical 
needs and problems that can be addressed by advanced technology. Good practices and lessons 
will  be  documented,  shared,  and  replicated.  Visits  to  institutions  in  regional  countries  where 
advanced technology is effectively implemented, and partnerships can be developed will also be 
considered. 
 
Output 3: Guidance material and knowledge products enhanced. The TRTA facility 
10. 
team will select suitable projects programmed for ADB processing during the period 2020-2022 
and use them to apply the knowledge acquired in related capacity building initiatives with a view 
of highlighting best practices in safeguards implementation.  
 
11. 
Individual  consultants  will  be  engaged  to  conduct  at  least  four  studies  on  international 
safeguard  best  practices  and  standards,  and  prepare  guidance  notes  and  manuals  on 
environment and social safeguards.  
 
C. 
 
12. 
The TRTA facility is estimated to cost $3.0 million which will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D. 
 
13. 
project concept paper on the ensuing project. 
 
ADB will administer the TRTA facility. The TRTA facility will commence in November 2019 
14. 
and will be completed by November 2022. SARD’s Portfolio, Results and Quality Control Unit is 
the  focal  point  within  ADB  and  will  be  responsible  for  the  coordination,  supervision,  and 
implementation  of  all  TRTA  facility  activities.  The  unit  will  be  responsible  for  the  selection, 
engagement  and  evaluation  of  consultants  and  will  manage  and  oversee  TRTA  facility 
implementation,  working  closely  with  the  sector  divisions,  and  resident  missions  within  SARD, 
and EAs/IAs in South Asia DMCs.

Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or  staff  instructions.8 The  TRTA  facility  will  be  implemented  by  international  and  national 
individual consultants (50 person months for international and 100 person months for national). 
Additional consultants may be recruited as needed. Given the diverse nature of the deliverables, 
some experts or resource persons as applicable for studies, training, or capacity development will 
be  recruited  individually  on  an  as-need  basis  or  to  undertake  specialized  technical  work  as 
requested by participating agencies and implementing agencies.  
 
17. 
A  mid-term  review  of  the  TRTA  facility  will  be  undertaken  after  18  months  of 
implementation to assess progress, fine-tune outputs, and, if necessary, adjust key activities and 
implementation  arrangements.  A  full  assessment  will  be  undertaken  upon  TRTA  facility 
completion to report on the achievements and results, and to share the lessons learned. 
 

II. 

THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 

 

18. 
The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Improving Safeguard Implementation in South Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
